>>69232995
I fucking dread eating and having to stuff my face way past the point of being full - but just like lifting it's just something you gotta do if you want to become big, it's part of the game. Now how to make things easier: Replace everything in your diet with a more calorie dense option or something that is easier to eat, easier to digest or less satiating. So for example, instead of potatoes you eat rice. Instead of chicken breast you eat chicken thighs, instead of beef mince you eat half and half beef and pork mince. Add butter, olive oil or similar to all meals. Make a sauce to go with all your meats (use the oil, fat and the juices from the meat as a base). I add peanut butter wherever the taste might suit, it's good in a curry. Put it in your protein shake, too. Hopefully you can handle your dairy. Cheese like gouda is great for bulking. 2 big slices on a sandwich with butter and that's a super easy 500+ kcal snack. Instead of water you drink milk - instead of skim milk you use full fat milk, instead of full fat milk in your coffee you use cream. Keep some vegetables in your diet but mostly go for those rich in vitamins that aren't very satiating, personally I eat a lot of bell peppers. Start eating early even if you're not the breakfast type or don't get hungry in the morning. Have like 4 eggs and something like whole wheat sandwich bread. You could probably just have a shake if you want. Throw in a banana and some peanut butter with the whey. Then I'd recommend making a big batch of a simple meal, for example a chili con carne. You can put in lots of beans, maybe throw in some sweet corn and cook some rice as a side or you could be making a big batch of some spaghetti bolognese or a stew or curry. This will be your main dish for the rest of the day or you can keep leftovers for the next day. Point is you cook once a day but make enough that it lasts you for at least 4 big servings.

Nigger get a new therapist. There is a new diagnosis for people like us, it's called CPTSD. Talk therapy does not work for this as effectively as the hypnosis/meditation style treatments where you recover and reprocess the memories. You can actually fix this shit instead of having to listen to that garbage self talk and living in the perpetual fear for the rest of your life. This problem was often misdiagnosed as bipolar before advancements (happened to me, but I never took the meds).

Additionally splitting like this is common with trauma. You're on this site, I'm sure you've read Frtiz's books on trauma and how it creates alters in the brain. In our case they were programmed by the environment and self preservation instead of being set up by handlers. You're not schizo, you just have an elaborate compartmentalized self defense and survival structure built into your brain that was to keep your child self alive in such a garbage environment.

I have a technique for you for the inner critic (the angry, self-hating representation of you who mentally beats you). That voice is a self created defense mechanism. It was made by your mind as a way to try to predict your retard parents confusing behaviour. By sparring against this voice you were able to survive and make it to adulthood. Now you don't need the voice to be like that anymore, so when it starts up try first asking it when it was formed. Mine was created at age 3 for example, and using meditation I was able to go back and reprocess the memory when it was formed.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>69231650
The inner critic is usually an inner child who has taken on a soldier/drill sargent role. Then try telling it that you are now safe from those shitbags and that negative self talk is actually hindering you. Tell it that you love them for trying so hard to keep you safe all these years, but that now they can rest and choose to do something new. Mine wants to keep defending so I tell it to keep an eye on things and help me analyse people's and my own behaviour. When they get too negative remind them that they are safe and that you are an adult now. Remind them that you are in charge, not the bad people, and that you will always love and defend them. Using this technique has been extremely effective for me and it only gets bad when I feel under threat from other people now, not always rational either, it's just anxiety sometimes when I'm worrying I've fucked something up.

Just treat it with love, but it will be hard for the alter to accept it and not mock you for being kind if you haven't reprocessed the memory and let it feel seen and understood. Good luck friend, I hope you can overcome this challenge. These days I can actually call myself a contented person and haven't had a serious, months long depressive episode in over a year (still get mini crashes, but they are gone in a few days with rest, good hydration and healthy food). This is with only one and a half years of this type of therapy. I also don't have mystery joint pain anymore, I lost weight, the nightmares are manageable instead of having to take drugs for them and I don't get headaches anymore. I hope you can find some peace because this shit is a bitch to live with anon.

com:
Go outside and enjoy the winter edition.

>Who is /fat/ for?
For corpulent custard consumers who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Yeah my goal weight is around 70kg and then keep it there. I originally started because one day i was sick and tired of being fat. Losing weight was relatively easy for me. I started good routines and stuck to it, every 10-15 kg i reduced the amount of calories i would eat.

Once i reached my goal weight for the first time i got lazy with tracking, started bad habits again and eventually gained back some weight slowly, occasionally i tried to go back down but never could muster the discipline to do it long enough.

My mindset right now is to keep going until the day i die. Going above 90kg again, having a bunch of clothes that don't fit me anymore was such a shit feeling that it kickstarted the urge to lose again.

I also know my biggest pitfalls from trying for so long. The biggest is poor sleep, waking up in the middle of the night and being tired all day leads to me being ravenous all day. If i sleep like shit i really gotta fight the urge to eat at 4 am and make it to a normal breakfast time. In general eating a scheduled time is really important for me.

>Advice for new runners
- Try to keep your cadence high (at or around 180 steps per minute)
- Try to keep your heartrate in Zone1/2 (around an average of 55-65% of your max. heart rate)
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 mi. (10km), start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training routine for that race

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
1. Genuine self improvement is hard, most people struggle with very basic stuff like eating properly and not watching netflix all day, so asking them to do something even beyond that is a pretty big step.
2. A bit of a hot take: long term self improvement is not a good thing, because if you think about it, it essentially implies there's something wrong with your life that you need to fix. If you have that mindset for too long, you'll feel miserable and unfulfilled, it's better to use self improvement strategically for certain periods of your life, and then go back to living normally. I feel like this mindset of constant self improvement that some guys claim is mostly marketing bs.
3. The self improvement industry is a scam. There is zero reason to ever shell out hundreds of dollars for an online course, literally all info on self improvement you could possibly need is already available for free.

There has been a few traditional masters, usually western ones, who have went on to successfully compete in MMA or have a military career. Jiang Yu Shan is one I can think of, that has a lot of content on YouTube and is worth watching.
The thing traditional Kung fu offers is a complete system to build and develop the internal body(myofacia, tendons, bones, vessels and internal organs) and that can be applied to any martial art and has been.
Stretching and movement routines, breathing and meditation techniques have been developed in every martial art around the world with the same purpose.
Knowing how to breathe properly and move your body efficiently can be applied in any situation.
I see people nowadays forget to breathe or hold their breath for the dumbest shit like climbing stairs.
Martial arts go deep, they are connected to spirituality at many levels. Developing the body, but also emotional and mental balance can be of tremendous help in the current world.
You can even discover some surprising things about your body while you're at it.

com: in terms of objective difficulty for men, the 3 pl8 squat is the easiest of the 1/2/3/4 assuming your training doesn't prioritize any of them more than the others.It's just a matter of learning the right form and how to brace yourself for the movement. Most advanced lifters can squat more than they deadlift. Next is overhead press which is generally easy as long as you aren't prone to shoulder injury. 2 pl8 bench with full rom is a noticably step up from this but in the same ballpark. the 4 pl8 deadlift is a big step up from the rest (for men, obviously for women the bench is borderline beyond of natty limits) while the other three are solidly middle of the road intermediate lifts, the 4 pl8 deadlift is late intermediate or even early advanced lift depending on bodyweight of the lifter

If you have never trained before and you're just fat I'd recommend starting out slow.
Just get used to the mechanics of the body, do not try to feed your ego with heavy lifting and God forbid cardio, you'll destroy your kidneys, which are probably already deficient from poor lifestyle and diet choices up to this point.
Start with bodyweight exercises, walks and light runs outside. Any breath coordinated movement is recommended, most people have a habit of stopping/holding their breath for even the dumbest shit like climbing stairs and think they lack cardio, when they can't even breathe normally.
Then dial in your diet, both macro and micro, take in more calcium, magnesium, zinc, potassium and sodium. Don't go for the OMAD meme, you shouldn't be that guy, it can actually cause damage to overeat so you can hit your macros. Try to keep your body in an anabolic state, which means many small meals, spread throughout the day with regulated carb intake to keep you from crashing and to restore your fucked up Insulin receptors. 18/6h or 16/8h intermittent fasting is the better option with 2-3 meals in the munching window.

Min-maxing your life can take you very far in all aspects, physical and mental health, money, social gains, etc.
There's always something more you can do in every situation, don't give up.
